page.title: Glossary of Texas A&M University terms

revisions.rev:
Many terms are unique to, or hold a special meaning connected with, [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas|College Station]], [[Texas]]. The University, often called A&M or TAMU, is a [[coeducation]]al [[public university|public]] [[research]] [[university]] and is the [[flagship#University campuses|flagship]] institution of the [[Texas A&M University System]]. It opened in 1876 as the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas, the first public [[Higher education|institution of higher education]] in that state.<ref name ="aboutTAMU">{{cite web | title = About Texas A&M University | publisher = Texas A&M University | url = http://www.tamu.edu/home/aboutam/ | accessdate = 20 February 2008}}</ref> In 1963, the [[Texas Legislature]] renamed the school to Texas A&M University to reflect the institution's expanded roles and academic offerings. The letters "A&M" no longer have any explicit meaning but are retained as a link to the university's past.<ref name="handbook1">{{cite web | last = Dethloff | first = Henry C. | title = Texas A&M University | date = 15 December 2005 | publisher = Handbook of Texas Online | url = http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/TT/kct8.html | accessdate = 28 February 2008 }}</ref>
As a [[Senior Military College]], Texas A&M is one of three public universities with a full-time, volunteer [[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets|Corps of Cadets]]. It provides more [[Officer (armed forces)|commissioned officers]] to the [[United States Armed Forces]] than any other school outside the [[United States Service academies|service academies]].<ref name="Bush Commencement Notes">{{cite news |url = http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/front/6161585.html|title =Bush urges A&M grads to consider a life of service|author=Kever, Jeannie|newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]]|date=12 December 2008| accessdate = 25 December 2008 }}</ref>
Texas A&M University's unique [[History of Texas A&M University|history]] as an all male military institution has led to a unique [[traditions of Texas A&M University|traditions]] and terminology. Some phrases come from traditions that include [[Aggie Bonfire]] and the [[Texas A&M Aggies|athletics]] program. Others phrases are locations and landmarks around the [[Campus of Texas A&M University|campus]]. While most of these terms are used exclusively by Aggies, some are used by the university's rivals. Terms exclusively used by the Corps of Cadets are not included to narrow the list size.
{{compactTOC2}}
==0â9== [[Image:Homeofthe12thMan.jpg|thumb|right|Texas A&M's football stadium, Kyle Field, student section with the sign "Home of the 12th Man"]] ;2 Percenters: Aggies who choose not to participate in [[Traditions of Texas A&M University|Texas A&M traditions]].<ref name="dictionary">{{cite web| title = The Aggie Dictionary| work=TheEagle.com| publisher=The Bryan-College Station Eagle| url = http://www.aggiesports.com/traditions/school/dictionary.htm| format = html| archiveurl =http://web.archive.org/web/20071014183528/http://aggiesports.com/traditions/school/dictionary.htm| archivedate = 2007-10-14| accessdate = 2011-01-03}}</ref><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="Chron5700">{{cite news| url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2000_3213207| title=A&M ponders scathing words in wake of Bonfire tragedy| newspaper=Houston Chronicle| accessdate=1 January 2009| date=7 May 2000| author=Nissimov, Ron}}</ref><ref name= "agathletics">{{cite web| title=Aggie Terminology| publisher=Texas A&M Athletics| date=2007|url= http://www.aggieathletics.com/index2.php?&CAT=TRD&pageID=221| archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080410200449/http://www.aggieathletics.com/index2.php?&CAT=TRD&pageID=221| archivedate = 2010-04-10| accessdate = 2011-01-03}}</ref><ref name="scharf">{{cite news|last=Scharf|first=Steve|title=Big 12 schools are rich in tradition|date=18 July 2008|publisher=The Daily Nebraskan| publisher=[[University of Nebraska]]| url=http://media.www.dailynebraskan.com/media/storage/paper857/news/2007/02/12/LifeStyle/Big-12.Schools.Are.Rich.In.Tradition-2711478.shtml | accessdate=25 December 2008}}</ref>
;[[12th Man (football)|12th Man]]: The student section in athletics events.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="sandiego">{{cite news | last = Greenwald | first = Michael | title = Crash course in Rooting for Aggies | publisher = [[San Diego Union-Tribune]] | date = 14 December 2006 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20061224/news_1s24am.html| accessdate = 25 December 2008}}</ref><ref name="beano">{{cite web| last=Cook |first=Beano |title=Ten Days That Shook the Sport |publisher=ESPN |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2615391 |date= 8 October 2006 |accessdate= 2 February 2008}}</ref><ref name="frozenlake">{{cite paper | author =Stanford, Frank S. | title =Escaping the Frozen Lake: Individual and Social Idealism Manifest As Forms of Religion and Religiosity: A Dissertation | publisher =Office of Graduate Studies of Texas A&M University | date =December 2003 | url =https://txspace.tamu.edu/bitstream/handle/1969.1/198/etd-tamu-2003C-SOCI-Stanford-1.pdf?sequence=1 | format =PDF | accessdate=13 September 2007|pages=109â110}}</ref><ref name="2002Traditions">{{cite news|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2002/09/02/Campus/Traditions.A.Major.Part.Of.Am.Life-518399.shtml |title=Traditions a major part of A&M life |accessdate=7 December 2008 |date= 9 February 2008 |newspaper=The Battalion}}</ref><ref name="SouthernCulture">{{cite paper | first = Meredith | last = Paddon | title = Southern Reveille: Southern Culture and Tradition at Texas A&M University | publisher = Texas A&M University | date = April 2007 | url = http://txspace.tamu.edu/bitstream/handle/1969.1/5726/thesisfinal.pdf?sequence=1 | format = PDF | accessdate = 9 January 2009}}</ref>
==A== ;A&M: The initials are part of institution's original name, the "Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas". Term no longer has any explicit meaning in the modern institution's name, but it remains as a link to the institution's past.<ref name="handbook1"/>
;Aggie: A student, alumnus, or supporter of Texas A&M University.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name= "sandiego"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name= "agathletics"/> Several other [[Aggie#Schools|land grant schools]] use "Aggie", such as [[New Mexico State]] and [[University of California, Davis]].<ref name= "otheraggie">{{cite web | title = New Mexico State Aggies | publisher = College Football Data Warehouse | url = http://cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/wac/new_mexico_state/index.php | accessdate = 18 February 2008}}</ref> The term is often used in its abbreviated form, "Ag".<ref name= "sandiego"/>
;"Aggies never lose, though they may run out of time": This quote or a variation is said after losing efforts. It gives voice to the idea that the team would have eventually won if the game would have gone on longer.<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref>{{cite news | url=http://aggietraditions.tamu.edu/team.shtml | title=Aggie Traditions | work=TAMU.edu | publisher=Texas A&M University | accessdate=2007-09-21}}</ref><ref name="Out scored">{{cite web | url=http://class.aggienetwork.com/heavens_11-72/traditions/twelfth_man.html | title=Aggie Traditions - Twelfth Man | accessdate=March 25, 2011}}</ref>
;[[Aggieland]]: Name for Texas A&M and the surrounding metropolitan area, [[BryanâCollege Station metropolitan area|BryanâCollege Station]], [[Texas]].<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name= "frozenlake"/><ref name="Chron5700"/><ref name= "agathletics"/><ref name="corpsdict"/> The phrase, "Welcome to Aggieland", was at the center of one of the university's marketing campaigns.<ref name= "Welcome">{{cite web | title = Welcome to Aggieland | publisher = Texas A&M University | url = http://www.tamu.edu/visit/ | accessdate = 27 January 2007}}</ref>
==B== [[Image:Aggiebonfire2005.jpg|right|upright|thumb|Student Bonfire, 2005]] ;Bad Bull: Anything not in keeping with Aggie traditions or the Aggie spirit.<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="corpsdict">{{cite web |url=http://b-batt.aggieband.org/dictionary.html |title=Corps Dictionary |accessdate=13 May 2007 |publisher=Texas A&M University| archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080803165914/http://b-batt.aggieband.org/dictionary.html| archivedate = 2008-08-03| accessdate = 2010-01-03}}</ref>
;Batt: Short for the [[Student newspaper|school newspaper]], ''[[The Battalion]]''.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="corpsdict"/>
;[[Aggie Bonfire]] (or Bonfire): A large [[bonfire]] built before the annual [[college football]] game against [[The University of Texas at Austin]].<ref name="SouthernCulture"/> Bonfire symbolizes a "burning desire to beat the hell outta t.u."<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="War Hymn">{{cite news | url=http://www.aggieband.com/story/warhymn.html | title=War Hymn | author=Harris, Patrick | accessdate=18 September 2007}}</ref> Aggie Bonfire at one time held the world record for the height of a bonfire at 109 ft, 10 in (33 m) tall.<ref name="WorldRec">{{cite web|last=Morris|first=Dave|date=8 December 1999| url=http://www.salon.com/books/it/1999/12/08/bonfire/index.html| title=Memories of an Aggie bonfire boy |publisher=[[Salon.com]]| accessdate=14 August 2007}}</ref> Due to the 18 November 1999 collapse of a Bonfire that killed 12 and injured 27,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/US/9911/18/students.crushed.02/|title=Texas A&M students killed, trapped in collapse of bonfire logs|publisher=CNN|accessdate=19 December 2008|date=18 November 1999}}</ref> recent non-university sanctioned Bonfires, called Student Bonfires, are now performed off-campus.<ref name="windle">{{cite news| last=Watkins|first=Matthew| title = Off-campus bonfire|newspaper=The Battalion | url =http://209.189.226.235/stories/110106/am_20061101007.php|date=17 November 2005| accessdate = 21 February 2008}}</ref><ref name="hensley">{{cite news|last=Hensley |first=Laura | title = A year after fiasco, student bonfire set to burn | publisher=The BryanâCollege Station Eagle | url =http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-153713246.html |date=1 November 2006 | accessdate = 3 March 2007 }}</ref>
;BQ: Member of the [[Fightin' Texas Aggie Band]], colloquially Band Queer, [[etymology|etymologically]] Band Qualified.<ref name="gravois"/>
;Bull: Active duty member (usually officer) in one of the U.S. armed services.
==C== ;[[Dixie Chicken (bar)|The Chicken]]: Short for a popular bar, Dixie Chicken, in the entertainment district, [[College_Station,_Texas#Northgate|Northgate]].<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="corpsdict"/>
;Aggie Code of Honor: Texas A&M's [[honor code]]: ''"Aggies do not lie, cheat, or steal, nor do they tolerate those who do."''<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name= "agathletics"/> The code is similar to the [[Cadet Honor Code]] used at the [[United States Military Academy]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Melgoza |first=Pauline |authorlink= |coauthors=Jane Smith |year=2008 |month= |title=Revitalizing an Existing Honor Code Program|journal=Innovative Higher Education |volume=32 |issue=4 |pages=209â219 |id= |url=|accessdate=2009-01-03 |quote= |doi=10.1007/s10755-007-9048-6 }}</ref>
[[Image:Fishreviewfall06.jpg|thumb|Corps of Cadets at [[#F|fish]] [[Military parade|review]] Fall of 2006]] ;Corps: Short for the [[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets]], Texas A&M's military college program. Though [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]] (ROTC) is mandatory for the first two years, military service is not.<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="SouthernCulture"/><ref name= "agathletics"/><ref name ="sforce">{{cite press release | title = 'Fish,' 'spurs' and 'zips': Equality Riders Experience military culture of Texas A&M | publisher = Soul Force | date = 2006-03-29 | url = http://www.soulforce.org/article/777 | accessdate = 2008-02-18}}</ref>
;Cut: The initial phase of Aggie Bonfire construction in which students cut down logs.<ref name="windle"/><ref name="homeland" />
;CT: Member of the Corps that are not in the [[Fightin' Texas Aggie Band|band]]. Colloquially "Corps Turd," etymologically "Cadet in Training".<ref name="gravois"/><ref name="WelcomeEnglish">{{cite web|title=New Student Booklet|url=http://www-english.tamu.edu/gs/egsa/files/New_Student_Booklet%5B1%5D.doc|publisher=Texas A&M University Department of English|accessdate=3 January 2011| format = doc}}</ref><ref>http://www.houstonpress.com/2008-01-24/news/rotten-to-the-corps-a-question-of-justice-at-texas-a-m/</ref>
==D== ;Dead (or Dead Elephant): Term that refers to senior undergraduates during their last semester. Word is a senior privilege.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="corpsdict"/><ref name="Dead">{{cite web |url = http://www.sanangeloaggiemoms.org/newsletters/dec_04.html |title = Elephant Walk |accessdate = 21 February 2008 |date = | publisher = San Antonio Aggie Moms| month = December | year = 2004 }}</ref>
==E== ;[[Elephant Walk (Texas A&M)|Elephant Walk]]: A tradition in which the senior class walks around campus to remember the times they had at Texas A&M.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name= "agathletics"/><ref name="abram">{{cite news|last=Abram|first=Lynwood|title=Earl Patterson, A&M's oldest drum major, 99|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|date=7 August 2002|accessdate=16 August 2007|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2002_3570501}}</ref>
==F== [[Image:TAMU Fishpond2.jpg|thumb|right|Fish Pond, a fountain on the Texas A&M campus]] ;"Farmers fight": Phrase used in several Aggie Yells.<ref name="sandiego"/>
;Fightin' Texas Aggie: Common [[prefix]] used for things related to A&M. For example, the Fightin' Texas Aggie Band.<ref name="frozenlake"/>
;[[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets#Freshmen|Fish]]: A freshman student.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name ="sforce"/>
;Fish Camp: An optional student led fourâday [[Retreat (spiritual)|retreat]] for incoming freshmen held before the student's fall semester that introduces them to the traditions of Texas A&M University.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name= "agathletics"/> [[College transfer|Transfer]] students can attend a separate retreat called "T-Camp",<ref name="Tcamp">{{cite web |url= http://t-camp.tamu.edu/|title= T-Camp|accessdate=11 January 2009 |year= 2009 |publisher= Texas A&M University: Student Activities}}</ref> and first time Texas A&M students coming in spring semester can attend "Howdy Camp".<ref name="howdycamp">{{cite web |url= http://howdycamp.tamu.edu|title= Howdy Camp|accessdate=11 January 2009 |year= 2009 |publisher= Texas A&M University: Student Activities}}</ref>
;Fish Pond: A fountain on the Texas A&M campus that is the part of several traditions.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/>
;[[List of Texas A&M University people#Notable Texas A&M former students|Former Student]]: Aggie graduates refer to themselves as "former students" rather than [[alumni]] because not all Aggies graduated due to military needs during the [[World War]]s.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="SouthernCulture"/><ref name= "agathletics"/> Another reason why Aggies use "former students" is that it is felt that "alumni" implies that graduates are "ex-Aggies". Aggies believe in the concept "once an Aggie, always an Aggie", and thus "alumni" would not be appropriate.<ref name= "agathletics"/> [[The Association of Former Students]] is the university's equivalent of an [[alumni association]].<ref name="aboutus">{{cite web | title = The Association of Former Students | publisher = The Association of Former Students | url =http://www.aggienetwork.com/TheAssociation/ | accessdate = 22 February 2008}}</ref>
;FOW (Freshman Orientation Week): Mandatory first week in the Corps just before school starts in the Fall semester for incoming freshmen cadets or Fish.<ref name="dictionary"/>
;Frog: Cadet in the corps who enlisted after being a freshmen.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="corpsdict"/>
;"From the outside looking in you can't understand it, and from the inside looking out you can't explain it": Phrase used to describe the difficulty outsiders have understanding Texas A&M culture, and Aggies have articulating their passion for Texas A&M.<ref name= "sandiego"/><ref name="SouthernCulture"/><ref name = "TMGates">{{cite news |last=Burka|first=Paul|publisher=[[Texas Monthly]]|title=Agent of change|date= November, 2006|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/preview/2006-11-01/feature|accessdate=2007-09-23}}</ref>
==G== [[Image:RobertGates TAMU SeniorBoots.JPEG|thumb|right|[[United States Secretary of Defense|US Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]] along with senior cadets from the Corps of Cadets give the "gig 'em" sign at the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]].]] ;[[Traditions of Texas A&M University#Gig 'em|Gig 'em]]: Both a saying and the [[thumbs signal|thumbs up]] hand gesture of all Texas A&M University current and former students as sign of affiliation.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="sandiego"/><ref name= "agathletics"/><ref name="pinky">{{cite news |last=Burka|first=Paul|publisher=Texas Monthly|title=Football Hand Signals | publisher = Emmis Publishing LP|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/ranch/readme/handsign.php|accessdate=10 July 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930013036/http://www.texasmonthly.com/ranch/readme/handsign.php <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 30 September 2007}}</ref> Gig 'em also is the name of an [[Traditions of Texas A&M University#Yells|Aggie yell]].<ref name="gigemyell">{{cite web| title=Yells| publisher=Texas A&M University [[Yell Leaders]]| url=http://yell.tamu.edu/yells/|accessdate=19 December 2007}}</ref>
;Good Bull: Anything that conforms to the traditions of Texas A&M.<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="2002Traditions"/><ref name="corpsdict"/>
;Grodes: The jeans and t-shirts worn by students who worked on Aggie Bonfire.<ref name="frozenlake"/> Grodes were typically not washed until Bonfire burned, if ever.<ref name="stratton">{{cite book|last=Stratton |first=W.K.|title=Backyard Brawl: Inside the Blood Feud Between Texas and Texas A&M|publisher = Crown| date=3 September 2002| pages =100â101 | isbn = 0609610538}}</ref>
==H== ;"Highway 6 runs both ways": A [[Social contract|contractarian]] argument used in response to complaints made about Texas A&M, meaning that those who do not like the university are free to leave.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="NewAggies">{{cite news |last=Burka|first=Paul|publisher=Texas Monthly|title=Did You Hear the One About The New Aggies?|date= 1 April 1997|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/1997-04-01/feature.php|accessdate=4 February 2008}}</ref> [[Texas State Highway 6|Highway 6]] refers to the major highway within the BryanâCollege Station area.
;Hiss (or horse laugh) : Rather than "booing", Aggies "hiss" to express disapproval. Aggies are not supposed to boo as a "sign of class", and are not supposed to hiss a fellow Ag.<ref name="sandiego"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="2002Traditions"/> Hissing is a part of a yell called a horse laugh, and usually is accompanied with a hand signal that consists of one's fingers open and palms clasped together, shaken backward and forward.<ref name="gigemyell"/>
;"Holler House on the Brazos": Another name for G. Rollie White Coliseum.<ref name="Holler">{{cite web | url=http://hlknweb.tamu.edu/articles/program_facilities | title=Facilities | publisher=Texas A&M University College of Education and Human Development | accessdate=April 13, 2011}}</ref> Term rarely used after basketball and volleyball games moved to Reed Arena.
[[Image:2007M&Wgame-HumpItAgs.jpg|thumb|right|Spectators and cadets "humping it" at the 2007 spring football [[exhibition game]]]] ;[[Traditions of Texas A&M University#Howdy|Howdy]]: Texas A&M University's official greeting. Students are encouraged to greet everyone they pass on campus with a smile and a howdy.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="howdy">{{cite web| url=http://aggietraditions.tamu.edu/community.shtml | title=Aggie Traditions | work=TAMU.edu | publisher=Texas A&M University | accessdate=21 September 2007}}</ref> Howdy is the preferred method for a speaker to get a large group's attention, as the members of the group are expected to return the "Howdy" back to the speaker.<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="2002Traditions"/><ref name="SouthernCulture"/>
;Hullabaloo, Caneck! Caneck!: Beginning phrase of the Aggie War Hymn.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="sandiego"/><ref name= "agathletics"/><ref name="Dead"/> The lyrics are an [[Onomatopoeia|onomatopoeic]] representation of the sound a cannon being loaded, or also the sound of a train rolling through town since there is a train track that splits the campus.
;Hump it (or Humping it): During a yell, the crowd leans forward and places their hands on their knees to maximize the noise and so that those standing behind them can see.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="sandiego"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name= "agathletics"/><ref name="corpsdict"/><ref name="schabach">{{cite web| last=Schabach| first=Mark| title=Texas A&M hoops finds place on football's back | publisher=ESPN| url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/columns/story?columnist=katz_andy&id=2625264| date= 14 October 2006| accessdate= 26 July 2007}}</ref>
==J== [[Image:G Rollie White Coliseum.jpg|thumb|right|G. Rollie White Coliseum, also known as Jollie Rollie]] ;Aggie jokes: [[Jokes]] used against Texas A&M and Aggies, similar to [[Ethnic joke|jokes]] used against [[ethnic minorities]]<ref>{{cite journal |last=Bynum |first=Joyce|year=1991|month= |title="Ethnic" Jokes and Texas Aggies |journal=ETC:: A Review of General Semantics |volume=48 |issue=3 |pages=320â328 |issn=0014164X|accessdate=3 December 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Wukasch|first=Charles|title=American Numskull Tales: The Aggie Joke|year=1969|month=July|pages=214â215|issue=3|volume=28|accessdate=3 December 2008|issn=0043â373X|journal=Western Folklore}}</ref> usually with a connotation of a lack of intelligence or unsophistication.<ref name= "sandiego"/><ref name="Dead"/><ref name="joke">{{cite web | last = Johnson | first = Judy | title = Aggie Jokes| work = ENG123 Texas Culture | date = 2002-04-29 | url = http://www.nvcc.edu/home/ataormina/jujohnson5/texas/texasjokes.html | accessdate = 2008-01-27 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20041121150559/http://www.nvcc.edu/home/ataormina/jujohnson5/texas/texasjokes.html |archivedate = 2004-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Football with a Difference|publisher=''The Saturday Evening Post''|year=1978|author=Read, Nat B. Jr.|pages=126â127|accessdate=24 May 2008}}</ref>
;Jollie Rollie: Nickname of [[G. Rollie White Coliseum]].<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name ="agathletics"/>
==K== ;[[Kyle Field]]: The Texas A&M [[American football|football]] [[stadium]].<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/>
==L== ;Load: The second phase of Aggie Bonfire construction in which the newly cut logs were brought back to campus.<ref name="homeland" />
==M== [[Image:Tamu MSCFlag.JPG|thumb|right|The flag room of the Memorial Student Center, also known as the MSC]]
;[[Maroon (color)|Maroon]]: The official color of Texas A&M along with white.<ref name="Chron5700"/> The University's specific trademark color is a custom [[Pantone]] color, Aggie Maroon ([[Web colors|Hex]] #500000).<ref name= maroon>{{cite web| title = Texas A&M University Brand Guide |publisher = Texas A&M Division of Marketing and Communications |year = 2008 |url = https://brandguide.tamu.edu/downloads/colorChart.pdf |format = PDF | accessdate = 22 October 2008}}</ref> [[Traditions of Texas A&M University#Maroon Out|Maroon Out]] is an official university tradition. Each year, one football game each season is dubbed an official Maroon Out event and discounted maroon t-shirts are offered for sale to fans to fill the stadium with the Texas A&M color.<ref name="SouthernCulture"/><ref name="maroonout">{{cite web|title=Maroon Out History|publisher=Maroon Out T-shirts|url=http://www.maroonouttshirts.com/|accessdate=26 July 2007}}</ref> The word "maroon" is used in other contexts, such as the name a student publication, the ''Maroon Weekly''.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Maroon Weekly: About Us| work=The Maroon Weekly| url=http://www.maroonweekly.com/about.aspx| accessdate= 30 June 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070823035514/http://www.maroonweekly.com/about.aspx <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 23 August 2007}}</ref>
;Mug down: Kissing one's date during [[Midnight Yell Practice|yell practices]] and football games.<ref name="mugdown">{{cite news |last=Haskins |first=Maggie |title=The Perfect Week |newspaper=Sports Illustrated on Campus|date=4 November 2004|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/sioncampus/11/03/perfect1104/| accessdate=13 January 2008}}</ref>
;[[Muster (Texas A&M University)|Muster]]: Tradition on April 21, [[San Jacinto Day]] in which Aggies from all over the world meet with each other and honor those Aggies who have died that year.<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="SouthernCulture"/><ref name="scharf"/><ref name="Muster">{{cite web |url = http://aggietraditions.tamu.edu/muster.shtml |title = Aggie Muster |accessdate = 26 December 2008 |publisher = Texas A&M University}}</ref><ref name="spencer">{{cite news|last=Spencer|first=Jason|title=Brother's death shows UT grad meaning of Muster|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|date=23 April 2004|accessdate=16 August 2007|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2004_3756556}}</ref>
;[[Campus of Texas A&M University#Memorial Student Center|MSC]]: Short for the Memorial Student Center, Texas A&M's [[student activity center]].<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="2002Traditions"/><ref name= "agathletics"/><ref name="corpsdict"/><ref name="NewAggies"/>
==N== [[Image:Dixie chicken in college station.jpg|thumb|right|Dixie Chicken back entrance on Northgate]] ;Non-reg: A student who is not in the Corps of Cadets.<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="corpsdict"/>
;[[College_Station,_Texas#Northgate|Northgate]]: A business and entertainment district located north of the Texas A&M campus.<ref name="SouthernCulture"/><ref name="corpsdict"/>
;Northside: Location of [[dormitories|residence halls]] on campus near Northgate.<ref name="northside">{{cite web| title=Northside Halls| publisher=Texas A&M University| year=2007| url=http://reslife.tamu.edu/housing/halls/location/northside.asp| accessdate=30 April 2007}}</ref>
==O== ;"Off the wood": During sporting events, Texas A&M students get off the bleachers when players on any team are injured. The term "wood" is only stated for tradition reasons because Texas A&M stadiums no longer have wooden bleachers.<ref name="ivey">{{cite news|last=Ivey|first=Tommi|title=Aggies should not walk on A&M seal|newspaper=The Battalion|date=19 October 2005|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2005/11/09/Opinion/Aggies.Should.Not.Walk.On.Am.Seal-1050633.shtml|accessdate=20 August 2007}}</ref>
;Old Ag: Synonymous for a former Texas A&M student.<ref name="SouthernCulture"/>
;Ol' Army (or Old Army): Term referring to Texas A&M's past.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="Chron5700"/><ref name= "agathletics"/>
[[Image:TAMUCHmural.jpg|upright|thumb|right|Aggie [[Habitat for Humanity]] mural at [[Camp Hope]], [[St Bernard Parish]], [[Louisiana]]. This is an example of the "other education".]] ;Other education: A term describing what Aggie students learn outside the classroom though [[extracurricular activities]] and through living life.<ref name="NewAggies"/><ref name= OtherEd>{{cite paper| first = Robin L. | last = Hughes | title = Traditions of Change: Student Expectations for the Other Education | year = 2007 | place = [[Montreal, Canada]] | date = 1 April 1999 | url= http://www.eric.ed.gov/PDFS/ED461341.pdf|format=PDF| id =ED461341 | accessdate=23 September 2007 }}</ref>
==P== ;Pass back: A hand signal, initiated by the [[#Y|Yell Leaders]], which informs students which yell to do next.<ref name="axtman">{{cite news|last=Axtman|first=Chris|title=Texas school where pompoms aren't welcome|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=6 November 2001 |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2001/1206/p3s1-ussc.html|accessdate=26 July 2007}}</ref>
;[[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets#Sophomores|Pisshead]]: A nickname for a sophomore cadet.<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="gravois">{{cite paper| title=Memorandum| last=Gravois| first=John| date=5 January 2007| publisher=[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]| volume=53| issue=18| page=A6| section=Short Subjects |quote=At A&M, we call our sophomore cadets "pissheads," we call our Fightin' Texas Aggie Band members "band queers,"}}</ref>
;Poor Aggies: Used to taunt Aggies after an athletic loss from opponents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/college/2003/preview/teams/texasam/|title=SI.com's 2003 Team Previews: Texas A&M Aggies|publisher=[[SI.com]]|work=Athlon Sports|accessdate = 5 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2004/12/07/Sports/Thoughts.On.Am.Football-823394.shtml|title=Thoughts on A&M football|newspaper=The Battalion|accessdate=5 January 2009|last=Millender|first=Shawn C.|date=7 December 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Turning corner to where?|publisher=''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]''|date=12 November 2006|accessdate=5 January 2009|last=Barnhouse|first=Wendell}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=It's a Real-Life Dallas Soap Opera Texas A&M Probe Somewhat Overshadows Cotton Bowl|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|accessdate=5 January 2009|date=30 December 1985|last=Hoffer|first=Richard}}</ref>
;Pots: [[Hard hat]]s worn by Aggie Bonfire builders. The color of a student's pot identified their [[Aggie Bonfire leadership|role in bonfire construction]].<ref name="corpsdict"/><ref name="2002bonfire">{{cite web | title = Official Bonfire 2002 website | publisher = Scout.com | url = http://tamu.scout.com/3/Trad_Bonfire.html | accessdate = 25 December 2008}}</ref>
;Privilege (SP, JP, ZP): A ranking system based on one's class year with determines what traditions and Aggie student is allowed to perform.<ref name="dictionary"/> The privilege levels are, SP, JP, and ZP's, sophomore, junior, and senior privileges respectively.<ref name="corpsdict"/> Freshmen have "''fish privileges''". In the Corps, one's privilege level has an enormous effect on a cadet's lifestyle.<ref name="frozenlake"/> Some rules like the wildcatting or whooping extend to non-regs.
;Pull out: Using a privileged word not available to your class; for example, sophomores saying "Whoop."<ref name="frozenlake"/>
;Push: a) A form of punishment consisting of [[pushups]], especially after pulling out. In the Corps when students do a "class set" of pushups, one for each year of their class. The Class of 1945 did only 45 pushups, but the Class of 2013 now does 113.<ref name="frozenlake"/> :b) The last phase of Aggie Bonfire construction, where students worked around the clock in rotating shifts to finish stacking the logs.<ref name="homeland">{{cite web | last = Cook | first = John Lee, Jr.| title = Bonfire Collapse, Texas A&M University | publisher = U.S. Fire Administration | url =http://www.usfa.dhs.gov/downloads/pdf/publications/tr-133.pdf |format=PDF| month = November | year = 1999 | accessdate = 3 March 2007}}</ref>
==Q== [[Image:TAMU quadarches2.JPG|thumb|right|Corps Arches in front of "the Quad"]] ;[[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets#Corps life|The Quad]]: Location of the dormitories of the Corps of Cadets.<ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="corpsdict"/>
==R== ;Ram: (n) Demerit issued to a cadet by either a ranking cadet or a [[bull]] for a major rule violation. (v) To receive demerits.
;RAggies: [[Texas A&M Aggies#Baseball|Aggie baseball]] fans.<ref name="Olsen Field">{{cite web| title=Road Trip: College Station, Texas| work=Sports Illustrated| url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/sioncampus/04/07/road_trip0408/| accessdate=9 June 2007}}</ref>
;Red Ass: Students who closely follow the Aggie traditions and rules.<ref name="smith2007">{{cite paper|last=Smith|first=Jonathan M|year=2007|title=The Texas Aggie Bonfire: A Conservative Reading of Regional Narratives, Traditional Practices, and a Paradoxical Place|publisher=Annals of the Association of American Geographers|pages=182â201|url=http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/action/showFullText?submitFullText=Full+Text+HTML&doi=10.1111%2Fj.1467-8306.2007.00530.x&cookieSet=1#Two%20Southern%20Narratives|accessdate=2007-08-15|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8306.2007.00530.x|journal=Annals of the Association of American Geographers|volume=97}}</ref>
;[[Reed Arena]]: The university's [[arena]].<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="reed">{{cite web | title = Reed Arena| publisher = Texas A&M University â Division of Finance| url =http://reed.tamu.edu/| accessdate = 19 December 2008}}</ref>
[[Image:Reveille-TAMU-Mascot.JPG|thumb|right|Reveille VII at a football game]] ;[[Reed Rowdies]]: Official [[fan club]] of [[Texas A&M Aggies basketball|Texas A&M basketball teams]].<ref name ="RRowdies">{{cite web | title = Reed Rowdies | publisher = Texas A&M University | url = http://reedrowdies.tamu.edu/| accessdate = 17 February 2008}}</ref>
;[[Reveille (Texas A&M)|Reveille]]: The Texas A&M mascot, a purebred American collie. Reveille is the highest ranking member of the Corps of Cadets.<ref name="sandiego"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="2002Traditions"/><ref name="brown">{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Chip|title=Some Aggies see red over moving grave site of mascots|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|date=21 July 1997|accessdate=2007-08-16|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1997_1425393}}</ref>
;[[Traditions of Texas A&M University#Aggie Ring|Ring dunk]]: A non school sanctioned tradition performed after a student receives an Aggie Ring; usually involves chugging a pitcher of beer, or a non-alcoholic substitute, with their Aggie Ring in the bottom then catching the ring in their teeth.<ref name="SouthernCulture"/><ref>{{cite web| last=Wirt| first=Ashley| url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2006/09/14/News/Aggies.Find.New.Ways.Of.ring.Dunking-2271747.shtml| title=Aggies find new ways of 'ring dunking'| date=9 September 2006 |accessdate=13 January 2008| work=The Battalion}}</ref>
==S== ;"Saw Varsity's Horns Off": A verse from the Aggie War Hymn,<ref name="sandiego"/><ref name="War Hymn"/> it refers to defeating the [[Texas Longhorns]], who use a [[Texas longhorn (cattle)|Longhorn steer]] as their mascot.<ref>{{cite news | title=Mascot Power Rankings | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/sioncampus/08/09/mascot.power.rankings/index.html | date=9 August 2007 | newspaper=Sports Illustrated | accessdate=20 September 2007}}</ref>
;Sea Aggies (or Sea Ags): Students or alumni of the school's branch campus, [[Texas A&M University at Galveston]].<ref name="SeaAgs1">{{cite news|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2009/09/11/News/Sea-Aggies.Readjust.To.Regular.College.Life.In.Galveston-3769003.shtml|title=Sea Aggies readjust to regular college life in Galveston|last=Willett |first=Lorelei|date=2009-09-11|publisher=The Battalion|accessdate=2009-09-21}}</ref><ref name="SeaAgs2">{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/headline/metro/6164650.html|title='Sea Aggies' return to Galveston for graduation|last=Kever|first=Jeannie|date=2008-12-14|publisher=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=2009-09-21}}</ref>
[[Image:Seniorboots.jpg|upright|thumb|right|Senior boots]] ;[[Senior boots#Senior boots|Senior Boots]]: Distinctive brown leather boots worn by Corps seniors, or [[#Z|Zips]].<ref name ="sforce"/><ref name="boottradition">{{cite web| title = Senior Boots â Texas Aggie Traditions | publisher = Texas A&M University | url = http://aggietraditions.tamu.edu/boots.shtml | accessdate = 25 December 2008}}</ref>
;[[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets#Juniors|Serge Butt]]: A nickname for a junior cadet.<ref name="corpsdict"/> Refers to the "serge" material used in making pants for juniors pre-1960. Usually abbreviated as just "butts."
;[[Texas A&M Singing Cadets|Singing Cadets]]: An all male [[choir]] at A&M, called the "Voice of Aggieland".<ref name="singingcadets">{{cite news | last =Edwards | first =Stacy | title = South American serenade | newspaper= The Battalion | date = 5 September 2008 | url = http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2007/09/05/News/South.American.Serenade-2950203.shtml | accessdate = 9 December 2008}}</ref>
;[[Traditions of Texas A&M University#Honoring the deceased|Silver Taps]]: A ceremony, held monthly, to honor all currently-enrolled students who died in the previous month.<ref name="2002Traditions"/><ref name="SouthernCulture"/><ref name="Chron5700"/><ref name="hegstrom">{{cite news|last=Hegstrom|first=Edward|title='Silver Taps' honors Aggie Bonfire victims|date=8 December 1999|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1999_3182335|accessdate=16 August 2007}}</ref>
;"Sit down bus driver": An Aggie Yell used in athletic events to taunt opposing team's [[Coach (sport)|coaches]] when they are arguing with an official or otherwise holding up the game. "Bus driver" refers to the fact that coaches used to drive the buses for road games.<ref name="sandiego"/>
;Southside: Residence halls on the far southeast portion of campus.<ref name="commons">{{cite web| title=Residence Halls by Style â Commons| publisher=Texas A&M University| year=2007| url=http://reslife.tamu.edu/housing/halls/style/commons.asp| accessdate= 30 April 2007}}</ref>
;Aggie Spirit (or [[Spirit of Aggieland]]): Abstract term that describes the unity and devotion Aggies have for their school and to each other.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="2002Traditions"/><ref name="spirit">{{cite web| title = Aggie Spirit | work = Official website of Texas A&M University Class of 72 | url = http://class.aggienetwork.com/heavens_11-72/traditions/aggie_spirit.html | accessdate = 13 January 2008}}</ref> "The Spirit" also refers to the [[Alma mater|school song]], ''The Spirit of Aggieland''.
;Stack: The third phase of Aggie Bonfire construction, where students would wire the logs together in their final shape.<ref name="SouthernCulture"/><ref name="homeland"/>
;Sully (or Sul Ross): Short for former Texas A&M President, [[Lawrence Sullivan Ross]]. Modern usage generally refers to the prominent statue of him.<ref name="frozenlake"/>
==T== ;TAMC (or Texas AMC): Refers to the university's former name the "Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas". While the institution has been renamed Texas A&M University with the initials TAMU, the initials AMC are still used in several Aggie traditions including Aggie yells and the Spirit of Aggieland."<ref name="handbook1"/>
;Tea-sip (or t-sip): A student of Texas A&M's archrival, The University of Texas at Austin.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name= "agathletics"/>
;t.u.: What Aggies call The University of Texas at Austin, normally abbreviated UT, the main rival school to Texas A&M University. Term is intended to be derogatory.<ref name="War Hymn"/> Aggies maintain that UT is "a" university in Texas not "the" university of Texas. The t.u. therefore stands for "t<!---NOT A TYPO; it should NOT be capitalized--->exas university", with the lowercase letters being an added insult.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name= "agathletics"/><ref name="NewAggies"/>
==W== [[Image:Wrecking-crew.png|thumb|right|Hand sign for the Wrecking Crew]] ;[[Fightin' Texas Aggie War Hymn|Aggie War Hymn]]: Texas A&M's [[fight song]].<ref name="SouthernCulture"/>
;Whip Out (or Whipping Out): The tradition of freshmen in the Corps of Cadets introducing themselves to upperclassman in the Corps.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="NewAggies"/><ref name="whipout">{{cite web| title=Joe B. Foster '56| month=October | year=2001| publisher=[[Mays Business School]]|url=http://maysbusiness.tamu.edu/old/2001/10/oaa-01/foster.html| last=Zuehlke| first=Lara| archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070522052749/http://maysbusiness.tamu.edu/old/2001/10/oaa-01/foster.html| archivedate = 2007-05-22| accessdate=2011-01-03}}</ref>
;[[White]]: The second official Texas A&M color.<ref name="Chron5700"/><ref name= maroon/> White Out is a basketball tradition. Unlike football games, where Aggie fans wear Maroon, the basketball crowds wear white.<ref name="huffman">{{cite news|last=Huffman|first=Holly|title=Attendance at Reed Arena rises with number of wins|publisher=BryanâCollege Station Eagle|date=27 January 2007|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-158477690.html|accessdate=26 July 2007}}</ref>
;"Whoop": An exclamation of approval and excitement, especially used at the end of a yell. Only juniors and seniors have the privilege to "Whoop".<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="pollyhughes">{{cite news|last=Hughes |first=Polly Ross |title=Aggie Spirit |newspaper=Houston Chronicle |date=28 November 1999 |url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1999_3180333|accessdate=16 August 2007}}</ref>
;Wildcat: A noise and a hand motion made after an Aggie yell. Each class uses a different wildcat based on seniority.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="frozenlake"/><ref name="2002Traditions"/>
<!-- Before editing the Wrecking Crew term, please see talk page --> ;[[Texas A&M Aggies football#Wrecking Crew|Wrecking Crew]]: Name given to defenses of the [[Texas A&M Aggies football|football team]].<ref name="liffick">{{cite news|last=Ruff |first=Brian |title=Wrecking Crew salvages A&M season opener |newspaper=The Battalion |date=30 September 2001 |url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2001/09/02/Sports/Wrecking.Crew.Salvages.Am.Season.Opener-512762.shtml|accessdate=17 February 2008}}</ref><ref name="Blackshirts_WC">{{cite web| last = Griffin | first = Tim| title = Revisiting the 'Wrecking Crew' and 'Blackshirts'| publisher = ESPN | date = 28 July 2008 | url =http://espn.go.com/blog/big12/post/_/id/92/revisiting-the-wrecking-crew-and-blackshirts| accessdate = 3 January 2011}}</ref> The term became popular during in 80s and the 90s. Many fans, coaches, and sports analysts feel that recent Aggie defenses have not "earned" the title.<ref name="Blackshirts_WC"/><ref name="DarnellWC">{{cite web | last = Onan | first = John | title = Aggies defense must earn âWrecking Crewâ label | publisher = Real Football 365| date = 6 March 2006 | url = http://www.realfootball365.com/articles/texasam/8829 | accessdate = 3 December 2008}}</ref>
==Y== [[Image:AggieYellLeader.jpg|thumb|upright|A yell leader doing the senior wildcat on the field at a football game. Yell leaders do this signal at the end of each yell either kneeling (as shown) or standing with the a foot tucked behind the opposite knee.]] ;[[Traditions of Texas A&M University#Yells|Aggie Yells]]: [[Cheering#Chants in North American sports|Synchronized cheers]] done at Aggie sporting events.<ref name= "frozenlake"/><ref name="SouthernCulture"/>
;[[Aggie Yell Leaders|Yell Leaders]]: Texas A&M's equivalent of [[cheerleading|cheerleaders]] â These elected students, three seniors and two juniors, lead the student body in synchronized yells throughout all sporting events and yell practices.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="sandiego"/><ref name="schabach"/><ref name="alvaradoyell">{{cite news | last =Alvarado | first =Nicole | title = Yell Leaders represent Aggie Spirit past, present, and future | newspaper=The Battalion | date=20 April 2007 | url =http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2007/04/20/News/Yell-Leaders.Represent.Aggie.Spirit.Past.Present.And.Future-2870762.shtml | accessdate=29 May 2007}}</ref> While all yell leaders on the main campus have been male, a female has served as one at the school's [[Texas A&M University at Galveston|branch campus in Galveston]].<ref name="FemaleYell">{{cite news|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2005/09/20/News/First.Woman.Yell.Leader.Elected.At.AmGalveston-990777.shtml|title=First woman yell leader elected at A&M-Galveston|last=Filbin|first=Melissa|date=2005-09-20|publisher=The Battalion|accessdate=2009-09-21}}</ref>
;[[Midnight Yell|Yell practice]]: A Texas A&M event that is similar to a [[pep rally]]. The most notable yell practices, Midnight Yell, occurs the night before home football games.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name= "agathletics"/><ref name="schabach"/>
==Z== ;[[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets#Seniors|Zip]]: A nickname for a senior, named so for the black and [[gold braid]] on the [[garrison cap]]s of seniors in the Corps of Cadets, which resembles a zipper.<ref name="dictionary"/><ref name="corpsdict"/><ref name ="sforce"/>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== {{Portal|Texas A&M University}} {{Commons|Texas A&M University}} *[http://web.archive.org/web/20080803165914/http://b-batt.aggieband.org/dictionary.html Corps dictionary] â An archived web page which was in depth dictionary of Corps of Cadets exclusive terminology *[http://www.tamu.edu/ Texas A&M University]
